channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [PDFBOX-5809] PDDocument#importPage slowed down by factor 1300
item.description:
We are using the PDDocument#importPage Method in our own splitter where we split pages from a SourceDocument to a TargetDocument. In order to do so we first extract the page by using the following code:

final PDPage sourcePage = sourceDocument.getPage(pageNumber);

Immediatly afterwards we are calling:

final PDPage targetPage = targetDocument.importPage(sourcePage);

This approach worked just fine with pdfbox 2.0.26.
We decided to upgrade to version 3.0.2 since it takles a lot of the problems.

Unfortunately the PDDocument#importPage method slowed down by around 1300 times. In Version 2.0.26 it took 15ms in an average. With the latest 3.0.2 it takes 20000 ms in average. That is a huge deal breaker as we usually have to split documents which have several thousand pages.

Note: The same applies when using PDDocument#addPage.
Note: The problem does not appear in 3.0.1. But we can't use that since it has other major problems which breaks our application.

I have prepared an example document with which you can replicate the issue. Due to the file size limitation I had to prepare a WeTransfer-Link for you: https://we.tl/t-lfN2wz7cAs

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Ouch, it happens with the trunk. I tried split with the command utility and "-startPage 1 -endPage 10" and it took 30 minutes.

There are four problems:

1) The file has "beads" (an obscure concept of PDF that is intended for following the "flow" of magazine / newspaper articles over several pages), which results in many "orphan pages" in the result (source page dictionaries in the result document). This has been in earlier versions too

2) The file has popup annotations and some of them indirectly link back to the page itself. This is being handled in the splitter, with the exception of the parent of popup annotations that are not in the page annotation list, so these are missed and they link to the source page dictionary, which would be an "orphan page" in the result document

3) A lot of time is spent in setHighestImportedObjectNumber(), maybe because the file is so big. This is only in 3.0 and higher.

4) The result file is still huge even when removing the beads during importPage(). A look at it with PDFDebugger shows orphan pages in the cross reference view.

(3) and (4) may be because of (1) and (2).
I have a fix for (1) and (2) which I'll commit in the next few days. This also fixes (4). (3) is still slow, sometimes.

Commit 1917394 from Tilman Hausherr in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1917394 ]

PDFBOX-5809: avoid orphan pages through beads and annotations

Commit 1917395 from Tilman Hausherr in branch 'pdfbox/branches/3.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1917395 ]

PDFBOX-5809: avoid orphan pages through beads and annotations

Commit 1917396 from Tilman Hausherr in branch 'pdfbox/branches/2.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1917396 ]

PDFBOX-5809: avoid orphan pages through beads and annotations; remove parent entry

I do now understand why setHighestImportedObjectNumber() is still slow for some pages. This is because importPage() doesn't fix the page destinations. Page 2 is an example for this, it has a product link to a page far away so we have an orphan page. This is handled in the splitter code (see PDFBOX-1618 and PDFBOX-5762) because it can't be fixed earlier, because we don't know which page destinations exist in the destination document. Btw check your own splitter for this.

The change has a flaw, it changes the original document; while this won't do harm in most cases, it's still unexpected behavior.
I also forgot my change from not long ago about the structure tree, annotations are cloned in the splitter (also because of /P entries) and the splitter keeps track of the original-clone-relationship and the structure tree gets updated with the cloned annotations.

Commit 1917402 from Tilman Hausherr in branch 'pdfbox/branches/3.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1917402 ]

PDFBOX-5809: revert because it changes source document and interferes with the structure tree changes in splitter

Commit 1917403 from Tilman Hausherr in branch 'pdfbox/branches/2.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1917403 ]

PDFBOX-5809: revert because it changes source document and interferes with the structure tree changes in splitter

Commit 1917404 from Tilman Hausherr in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1917404 ]

PDFBOX-5809: revert because it changes source document and interferes with the structure tree changes in splitter

tilman Thank you for your in depth analysis.

Our splitter cleans the mentioned remains and far more than the on-board splitter does after splitting the original document.
The clean-up is done after in order to avoid changing the original file accidentally - although it might be clever to temporarily change the original document (or to create a copy) before splitting it.

Any reason why it was so much faster in the 2.X versions? - I also thought it was fast in 3.0.1. Hmm

Is this likely to get fixed with the release of 3.0.3?

Thanks for your effort!

Re changing the original document, I meant changing its representation in memory, I want to avoid this, because it's a surprising behavior. The physical file would only be changed if saved.

The "why so much faster" in 2.0.X is because of setHighestImportedObjectNumber() which is a call done only in 3.0.X to fix a nasty problem (broken documents) when combining documents. This problem happens only in 3.0.X because of the on-demand parser or because of ObjectStream compression when saving. The call is slow with your document because of the page references in the annotations and in the beads, which in turn references other pages so the call ends up crawling through the whole document.

Is this likely to get fixed with the release of 3.0.3? I don't know.

Alternative: remove all annotations and page /B entries before splitting. Or try PDFSam which is based on a PDFBox fork.

Thank you for the explanation.

I am going to try the alternative of first clearing everything we do not need from the original document.
We only need GoTo's which point to the same page and of course Links which lead to websites (for the splitted result files).

Thank you for suggesting PDFSam but I'd rather stay with pdfbox

Thanks again for your effort!

PDFBOX-5809: remove /B entry

PDFBOX-5809: fix references for popup annotations and their parent, clone if needed

Commit 1917454 from Tilman Hausherr in branch 'pdfbox/branches/3.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1917454 ]

PDFBOX-5809: fix references for popup annotations and their parent, clone if needed

Commit 1917455 from Tilman Hausherr in branch 'pdfbox/branches/2.0'

PDFBOX-5809: fix references for popup annotations and their parent, clone if needed

Commit 1917456 from Tilman Hausherr in branch 'pdfbox/branches/2.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1917456 ]

PDFBOX-5809: add test file

(1), (2) and (4) are fixed once again, but not (3) due to the different approach. Let's wait if others have better ideas. If we can't solve this then you should stay with 2.0 for splitting which does not have the slowness problem, but will have bigger result files because compressed object streams aren't supported, which is mostly relevant for files with a structure tree (accessibility).

Thank you for your fast response and fixes.

Staying at 2.0 is not really an option as 2.0 has a lot of problems when splitting documents.
This was the original trigger to change to 3.0. Also 3.0 seemed to fix a lot of the problems which were present in 2.0.

Unfortunately 3.0.1 introduced a few new bugs which were fixed in 3.0.2, but again 3.0.2 has the problem with the slow splitting (which was not the case in 3.0.1).
3.0.2 seems to be able to split documents even if they have a "malformed content stream" as it just logs a warning and splits it anyways instead of throwing an exception.

Regarding (3): A lot of our documents are even bigger, up to 2GB, but most of them are in the region of 200-300MB like the sample I have sent you. Our documents also have up to 20k pages, but most of them are in the region of 500-700. The documents are provided and created by 3rd parties, therefore we have no control over the incoming documents, but we have to split them and fix as much as we can while doing so, to prevent huge file sizes. At the moment we have a very stable splitter which is capable of splitting 99.99% of all provided documents in a way so that we do not have huge or bloated (big) files. For this reason we also have an implementation of the `PDFStreamEngine` (and `OperatorProcessor`) which makes sure that images, which are not presented on the page, are removed from the resources...

Regarding (3) and `setHighestImportedObjectNumber`: Would it be an option to give control wether the method should be called via a config value or a flag?

Thank you very much!

PDFBOX-5809: recursion protection only needed for objects that allow recursion (change needed because identical integers weren't displayed)
Re setHighestImportedObjectNumber I'll pass this decision to lehmi because he knows more about that part of the code.

Commit 1917472 from Tilman Hausherr in branch 'pdfbox/branches/2.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1917472 ]

PDFBOX-5809: remove diamond

I just wanted to let you know that stripping all "unnecessary" information before splitting the page from the source page worked like a charm.

final PDPage sourcePage = sourceDocument.getPage(pageNumber);
stripUnnecessaryDataFromPage(sourcePage, pageNumber);
final PDPage targetPage = targetDocument.importPage(sourcePage);
...
stripUnnecessaryDataFromPage(targetPage, pageNumber);

The only "downside" is that we have to call the stripUnnecessaryDataFromPage twice, but the call is super fast, especially the seconds time as most of the stuff gets cleared the first time.

The link is outdated and the sample pdf no longer available for download. Is there any chance to reactivate the link or do we have another sample demonstrating the issue with setHighestImportedObjectNumber
I've uploaded it to wetransfer, you should get a mail; alternatively try this link: https://we.tl/t-1XKMW18p45
tilman thanks, it works and I'm already running some tests

Commit 1917514 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1917514 ]

PDFBOX-5809: cache keys of imported indirect objects to speed up the processing of big documents

Commit 1917515 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/branches/3.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1917515 ]

PDFBOX-5809: cache keys of imported indirect objects to speed up the processing of big documents

I've sped up setHighestImportedObjectNumber by caching all keys of indirect objects throughout the document. On my system the time for saving the first 10 pages went down from 140 to 18 seconds. But that is still 10 times slower that 2.0
Also if you split the document, the current 3.0.2 version is at least 1000 times slower than 2.X.
I did my test with the current trunk including Tilmans and my optimizations. Looks like we are down from 1000 times slower to 10 times slower

Thats great news so far. =)
Now lets make it 10 times faster :-D

Although stripping stuff before splitting the file is also a very good approach to increase the general performance.

Hello,

I would like to let you know that Splitter is also very slow compared to previous versions.
Since 2.0.31 we have noticed a big slowdown, for example we use 160 MB files with about 5000 pages with accessibility tags, to split into 5, 6 or 8 pages it takes 600/700 ms while before 20 ms but now the accessibility tags are correct.

I do not notice any difference in speed between 2.0.31 and 2.0.32-SNAPSHOT.

This ticket is about the splitter

Did you give the 3.0.3.-SNAPSHOT a try? There should be an improvement compared to 3.0.2
androidominus that's because the splitter now handles the accessibility tags.

Hello,
sure and I would like to thank you very much for the feature.
Anyway, I haven't tried 3.0.2 but 3.0.3-SNAPSHOT is even slower than the 2.0.32-SNAPSHOT.
Same JVM, same file, same split pages, 200ms slower on average.
Please open a separate ticket for that if you can attach a file. There was a bug in splitting (PDFBOX-5792) but it was related to annotations with destinations, with parts getting ignored in 3.0.2.

Commit 1918267 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/trunk'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1918267 ]

PDFBOX-5809: use HashSet instead of ArraysList to speed up the import of pages

I've found a way to speed up the import page process another time so that the performance is similar to 2.0.x. For now the change is limited to the trunk as it includes a breaking change, but I'm pretty sure to find a workaround for 3.0.x as well
I was wondering if the change of the type within the method signature from List to Collection is a breaking change or not? Any opinions?

Commit 1918274 from lehmi@apache.org in branch 'pdfbox/branches/3.0'
[ https://svn.apache.org/r1918274 ]

PDFBOX-5809: use HashSet instead of ArraysList to speed up the import of pages

I've found the answer myself, changing the type of a parameter seems to be always a breaking change, ever if the new type is a more general one.

We are done here, set to reolved

mko91 thanks for the report

tilman thanks for your help
